title: Tentative T Cells: Memory Cells Are Quick to Respond, but Slow to Divide
predicted summary: Memory T cells are thought to initiate cell division much faster than their nave counterparts, thus confering a significant biological advantage upon an immune host. Here, we use traceable TCR-transgenic T cells to evaluate this proposed characteristic in both memory T cells and their nave counterparts. Both memory T cells can detect virus infection within a few hours, but their proliferation did not begin until 3 days after infection, and occurred simultaneously simultaneously in all anatomical compartments simultaneously in all anatomic compartments simultaneously simultaneously simultaneously in all compartments simultaneously.

title: Hyperthermia Stimulates HIV-1 Replication
predicted summary: Fever is an elevation of body temperature accompanied by inflammation. It is usually beneficial for the host through enhancement of immunological defenses through enhancement of immunological defense mechanisms. However, the effects of physiological hyperthermia (38–40°C) on HIV infection has not been extensively investigated. Here, we show that physiological hyperthermia increased the efficiency of HIV replication by 2 to 7fold at 39.5°C. Hyperthermia did not facilitate viral entry nor reverse transcription, but enhanced Tat transactivation of the LTR viral promoter. Hyperthermia did not facilitate viral entry nor reverse transcription but increased Tat transactivation of Tat Promoter promoter activity. We further show that Hsp90 colocalized with actively transcribing proviruses and this phenomenon was enhanced at 39.5°C at 39.5°C.

title: Th1-Biased Immunomodulation and Therapeutic Potential of Artemisia annua in Murine Visceral Leishmaniasis
predicted summary: Visceral leishmaniasis (VL) is fatal, if left untreated. Development of safe and efficacious drugs is urgently needed for cure against Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL), which is fatal if left untreated. Here we report the two-prong antileishmanial activity of Artemisia annua leaves and seeds against Visceral Leishmania Donovani that is dependent upon both direct antileishmanial action as well as switching-on of Th1-biased protective cell responses with generation of memory. Our results establish the two-prong antileishmanial efficacy of Artemisia annua leaves and seeds for cure against Visceral Leishmania donovani that is dependent upon both direct antileishmanial action and switching-on of Th1-biased protective cell responses with generation of memory.

title: Inferring the Joint Demographic History of Multiple Populations from Multidimensional SNP Frequency Data
predicted summary: Demographic models built from genetic data play important roles in illuminating prehistoric events and serving as null models in genome scans for selection. Our approach accurately predicts the frequency spectrum of genetic variants within and between populations across three continents (YRI, CHB, CEU, and MXL). We combine our method with previously estimated distributions of selective effects among newly arising amino acid mutations. We estimate divergence between West African populations 140 thousand years ago (95% confidence interval: 40–270 kya), long after archaeological evidence places modern humans out of Africa and settlements of the New World, long after archeological evidence places modern humans out of Africa and settled in the New World.
